4.28.21  12:51 am   i'm pretty much a beginner when it comes to writing music. i don't know a lot about music theory or anything, i just really love music. after listening to you, jacob collier and other musicians that i admire, i find myself wanting to create something unique too, but every time i try to write what sounds and feels good, i feel like i end up with a generic chord progression or a simple melody. sure, less can be more, but do you think it's worth it if it stops being unique?

4.28.21  12:31 am   if you could choose a month to celebrate a new year (disregarding when the earth finishes a revolution or the fact that different parts of the world experience different seasons), which month would you choose?

     personally, i sort of hate the fact that the new year starts 1/3 of the way into winter for where i live. do you think that celebrating a new year amid the austerity of winter contributes to some people giving up on their goals for the new year?

     do the seasons affect your motivation/mood?

      and do you find it helpful to observe days that signify change (new years, birthdays, etc) to make changes in your own life?

4.27.21  11:21 pm   Hi!! First off, I want to say that I am consistently in awe of your music and I love how your videos complement the songs so well (and so artistically). You're one of my favorite artists of all time and I rank you up at the top in my list of favorites, along with the Beatles, Steely Dan, and the Beach Boys. I'm also grateful that you offer a place to share your knowledge and humor with your fans - it's a very unique opportunity to talk directly with someone who inspires you.

     okay enough yammering here's my question:
When writing your songs, are you usually putting words to music or putting music to words? I ask because I see you also used to do instrumentals. I'm woefully bad at lyrics, and a lot of the time I'm not even compelled to write them, because I stubbornly believe maybe the music I create will convey the emotions I'm trying to express on its own. Do you make your music with an emotion/other goal in mind and then write lyrics to m atch it, or do you write your lyrics and then write music to match? If you do both, have you found that your final products tend to be different depending on your method, and in what way(s)?

     Thanks in advance so much for answering!
